questions.question: Which of the following is a natural method of contraception?
questions.explanation: Lactational amenorrhoea method (LAM) is a natural contraceptive method based on the fact that ovulation does not occur during the period of intense lactation following parturition. It is effective up to 6 months after delivery.

questions.question: Cu-T is an example of:
questions.explanation: Cu-T (Copper-T) is an Intra-Uterine Device (IUD) that releases copper ions which are spermicidal and also create an unfavourable environment in the uterus for implantation. It is a non-hormonal IUD.

questions.question: Vasectomy involves cutting and tying of:
questions.explanation: Vasectomy is a male sterilisation procedure where a small portion of the vas deferens is cut and tied through a small incision in the scrotum. This prevents sperm from being transported during ejaculation.

questions.question: Amniocentesis is a technique used to:
options: Determine the sex of the foetus
Detect genetic disorders in the foetus
questions.explanation: Amniocentesis is a prenatal diagnostic technique where amniotic fluid is analysed for chromosomal abnormalities and metabolic disorders of the foetus. Its misuse for sex determination is banned by law in India.

questions.question: GIFT (Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer) involves:
options: Transfer of ovum and sperm into the fallopian tube
Transfer of zygote into fallopian tube
Transfer of embryo with more than 8 cells into uterus
questions.explanation: GIFT involves the transfer of an ovum collected from a donor into the fallopian tube of another female who cannot produce ova but can provide a suitable environment for fertilisation and development.

questions.question: The most widely accepted method of contraception in India is:
questions.explanation: Tubectomy (female sterilisation) is the most widely accepted method of contraception in India. It is a permanent surgical method where fallopian tubes are cut and tied to prevent the ovum from reaching the uterus.

questions.question: Which STD is caused by a virus?
questions.explanation: Genital herpes is caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV). Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum (bacterium), Gonorrhoea by Neisseria gonorrhoeae (bacterium), and Chlamydiasis by Chlamydia trachomatis (bacterium).

questions.question: IVF (In Vitro Fertilisation) involves:
options: Transfer of gametes into fallopian tube
Fertilisation outside the body in laboratory conditions
questions.explanation: IVF involves fertilisation of ovum with sperm outside the body in laboratory conditions (in vitro means 'in glass'). The embryo is then transferred to the uterus or fallopian tube for further development.

questions.question: Saheli is a:
questions.explanation: Saheli is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill developed by CDRI, Lucknow. It contains centchroman and is taken once a week. It has fewer side effects compared to hormonal pills.

questions.question: Which of the following STDs can be transmitted from mother to infant during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Syphilis and HIV can be transmitted from an infected mother to the foetus through the placenta (vertical transmission). Hepatitis B can also be transmitted in this way.

questions.question: Emergency contraceptive pills contain:
options: High dose of progestogen or progestogen-estrogen combination
questions.explanation: Emergency contraceptive pills (morning-after pills) contain high doses of progestogen or a progestogen-estrogen combination. They must be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to prevent pregnancy.

questions.question: ZIFT (Zygote Intrafallopian Transfer) involves transfer of:
options: Embryo with more than 8 cells into uterus
Zygote with up to 8 blastomeres into fallopian tube
questions.explanation: ZIFT involves transfer of the zygote or early embryo (up to 8 blastomeres) into the fallopian tube. If the embryo has more than 8 blastomeres, it is transferred into the uterus (IUT - Intra Uterine Transfer).

questions.question: Condoms are made of:
questions.explanation: Condoms are made of thin rubber/latex sheath. Male condoms cover the penis, while female condoms line the vagina. They act as barrier methods preventing sperm from entering the female reproductive tract and also protect against STDs.

questions.question: The causative organism of syphilis is:
questions.explanation: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It is a sexually transmitted disease characterised by chancre (painless ulcer) in the primary stage and can affect multiple organ systems if untreated.

questions.question: Which of the following IUDs releases hormones?
questions.explanation: LNG-20 (Levonorgestrel-releasing IUD) is a hormone-releasing IUD that releases the progestogen levonorgestrel. It makes the cervical mucus hostile to sperm and also thins the endometrium. Cu-T, Cu-7, and Multiload 375 are non-hormonal copper IUDs.

questions.question: Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is safe up to:
questions.explanation: MTP is considered relatively safe during the first trimester (up to 12 weeks of pregnancy). After this period, it becomes increasingly risky. In India, MTP is legal up to 20 weeks under the MTP Act with certain conditions.

questions.question: Diaphragm is a contraceptive device used by:
questions.explanation: The diaphragm is a dome-shaped rubber barrier device used by females. It is inserted into the vagina to cover the cervix, preventing sperm from entering the uterus. It is often used with a spermicidal cream.

questions.question: Test tube baby programme involves:
options: Fertilisation in vitro and embryo transfer to uterus
Growth of baby in test tube
Fertilisation in vivo followed by growth in test tube
questions.explanation: Test tube baby programme involves in vitro fertilisation (IVF) where ovum and sperm are fertilised in laboratory conditions, and the resulting embryo is transferred back to the uterus (ET) for further development.

questions.question: Genital warts are caused by:
questions.explanation: Genital warts are caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV). Some strains of HPV are also associated with cervical cancer. HPV vaccination is recommended for prevention.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a sexually transmitted disease?
questions.explanation: Typhoid is NOT an STD. It is a water-borne disease caused by Salmonella typhi. AIDS, Gonorrhoea, and Syphilis are all sexually transmitted diseases.

questions.question: Artificial insemination is useful when:
options: Male has very low sperm count or impotence
questions.explanation: Artificial insemination (AI) is used when the male partner has low sperm count, low motility, or cannot inseminate. Semen is collected from the husband/donor and artificially introduced into the female reproductive tract.

questions.question: Oral pills contain:
questions.explanation: Oral contraceptive pills contain synthetic progesterone or a combination of progesterone and estrogen. They prevent ovulation by inhibiting FSH and LH secretion through negative feedback, and also alter cervical mucus.

questions.question: Tubectomy involves the blocking of:
questions.explanation: Tubectomy is a female sterilisation procedure involving the cutting and tying of fallopian tubes (oviducts) to prevent the ovum from reaching the uterus and meeting sperm. It is a permanent contraceptive method.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be treated with antibiotics?
questions.explanation: Genital herpes is caused by a virus (HSV) and cannot be treated with antibiotics. Antibiotics are effective only against bacterial infections. Syphilis, Gonorrhoea, and Chlamydiasis are bacterial STDs treatable with antibiotics.

questions.question: The ideal contraceptive should be:
options: User-friendly, reversible, with minimal side effects
questions.explanation: An ideal contraceptive should be user-friendly, easily available, effective, reversible, have minimal or no side effects, not interfere with sexual drive or sexual act, and should be light-weight and easy to use.

questions.question: ICSI (Intra Cytoplasmic Sperm Injection) is used when:
options: Male produces very few or immotile sperm
questions.explanation: ICSI involves injecting a single sperm directly into the cytoplasm of the ovum to achieve fertilisation. It is used when the male has very low sperm count, poor motility, or abnormal sperm morphology.

questions.question: Which of the following is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
questions.explanation: Gonorrhoea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It affects the mucous membranes of the urogenital tract and can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease if untreated.

questions.question: RCH stands for:
questions.explanation: RCH stands for Reproductive and Child Health Care programme. It was launched by the Government of India to provide improved healthcare for reproduction, maternal health, and child health.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a chemical barrier method?
questions.explanation: Spermicidal creams, jellies, and foams are chemical barrier methods. They contain chemicals that kill or immobilise sperm. Condoms and diaphragms are physical/mechanical barrier methods. Cu-T is an IUD.

questions.question: Infertility in couples can be treated by:
questions.explanation: Infertility can be treated by various Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ART) including IVF-ET, ZIFT, GIFT, ICSI, and artificial insemination. MTP terminates pregnancy, amniocentesis is for diagnosis, and contraceptives prevent pregnancy.

questions.question: Hepatitis B is transmitted through:
questions.explanation: Hepatitis B is transmitted through sexual contact, contaminated blood or blood products, shared needles, and from mother to child during childbirth. It is caused by the Hepatitis B virus (HBV).

questions.question: Which of the following methods provides protection against STDs as well as pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Condoms (both male and female) provide protection against STDs as well as pregnancy. They act as a physical barrier preventing the exchange of body fluids. Other methods prevent pregnancy but not STDs.

questions.question: Trichomoniasis is caused by:
questions.explanation: Trichomoniasis is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection that commonly affects the urogenital tract, particularly in females.

questions.question: The periodic abstinence method (rhythm method) avoids coitus during:
questions.explanation: The rhythm method involves avoiding intercourse from day 10 to day 17 of the menstrual cycle when ovulation is expected (around day 14). This period is considered the fertile window.

questions.question: Which of the following is an injectable contraceptive?
questions.explanation: DMPA (Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate/Depo-Provera) is an injectable hormonal contraceptive given every 3 months. It contains progestogen that prevents ovulation and alters the cervical mucus.

questions.question: Surrogacy involves:
options: Another woman carrying the pregnancy for the couple
questions.explanation: Surrogacy involves another woman (surrogate mother) carrying and delivering the baby for the couple who cannot carry the pregnancy. The embryo may be from the couple's gametes or donor gametes.

questions.question: Which government programme aimed at achieving population stabilisation?
questions.explanation: The Family Planning Programme was initiated by the Government of India in 1951 to achieve population stabilisation. It was later renamed as Family Welfare Programme and integrated with Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) programmes.

questions.question: Which STD can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)?
questions.explanation: Gonorrhoea (Neisseria gonorrhoeae) and Chlamydiasis (Chlamydia trachomatis) can ascend to the upper genital tract and cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which may lead to infertility if untreated.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cu-T prevents pregnancy.
Reason (R): Copper ions released by Cu-T are spermicidal and increase phagocytosis of sperm.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. The Cu-T releases copper ions that are toxic to sperm (spermicidal), increase phagocytosis of sperm by leukocytes, and also create an environment unfavourable for implantation.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Oral pills are very effective with high failure rate.
Reason (R): Oral pills must be taken daily without missing doses.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are false
questions.explanation: The assertion is false because oral pills are very effective with LOW failure rate (not high). The reason is true as oral pills must be taken regularly without missing doses for maximum effectiveness.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Amniocentesis is banned in India.
Reason (R): It was being misused for sex determination of the foetus leading to female foeticide.
options: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: The assertion is false - amniocentesis itself is NOT banned in India. Its use for sex determination is banned under the PCPNDT Act. Amniocentesis is still legal for detecting chromosomal and genetic disorders. The reason is true.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Condoms are the most popular contraceptive among males.
Reason (R): Condoms are barrier methods that also protect against STDs.
options: A is false but R is true
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. Condoms are the most popular male contraceptive because they not only prevent pregnancy but also provide protection against STDs including HIV/AIDS, making them a dual-purpose contraceptive.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Vasectomy and tubectomy are highly effective contraceptive methods.
Reason (R): They are permanent methods that can be easily reversed.
options: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The assertion is true - vasectomy and tubectomy are highly effective. However, the reason is false because they are NOT easily reversed. While reversal is sometimes possible, it is not guaranteed and the procedures should be considered permanent.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Saheli has fewer side effects than hormonal pills.
Reason (R): Saheli is a non-steroidal contraceptive.
options: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. Saheli contains centchroman (a non-steroidal compound) and thus has fewer hormonal side effects compared to steroidal contraceptive pills that contain synthetic progesterone/estrogen.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): IVF babies are called test tube babies.
Reason (R): In IVF, fertilisation occurs outside the body in laboratory glassware.
options: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. The term 'test tube baby' refers to the fact that fertilisation occurs in vitro (in laboratory conditions/glassware). However, the embryo develops inside the mother's uterus after transfer.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Lactational amenorrhoea is effective for about 6 months.
Reason (R): Intense lactation suppresses ovulation by inhibiting GnRH release.
options: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. During intense lactation, high prolactin levels suppress GnRH release from the hypothalamus, which in turn suppresses FSH and LH, preventing ovulation. This method is effective only for about 6 months.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): STDs are also called venereal diseases (VD).
Reason (R): STDs are transmitted exclusively through sexual contact.
options: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: The assertion is true - STDs are also called venereal diseases. However, the reason is false because STDs are NOT transmitted exclusively through sexual contact. Some can also be spread through blood transfusion, sharing needles, and from mother to child.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): MTP is not a contraceptive method.
Reason (R): MTP terminates an already established pregnancy.
options: A is false but R is true
A is true but R is false
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) is not a contraceptive because it does not prevent pregnancy. It terminates an already established pregnancy and should not be used as a regular birth control method.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Population explosion is a major concern in India.
Reason (R): Improved healthcare has led to decreased death rate without a corresponding decrease in birth rate.
options: Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: Both are true and R explains A. Rapid population growth in India is primarily due to the decline in death rate (improved healthcare, better sanitation) while the birth rate has not declined proportionately.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about ART:
(i) IVF involves fertilisation outside the body.
(ii) ZIFT involves transfer of zygote into fallopian tube.
(iii) GIFT involves transfer of ovum into the uterus.
(iv) IUI involves introduction of semen into uterus.
Which are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (iii) is incorrect because GIFT involves transfer of an ovum collected from a donor into the FALLOPIAN TUBE (not uterus) of another female.

questions.question:
Read the statements:
Statement I: Surgical methods of contraception are also called sterilisation.
Statement II: Both vasectomy and tubectomy are reversible procedures.
questions.explanation: Statement I is correct - surgical methods (vasectomy and tubectomy) are also called sterilisation procedures. Statement II is incorrect because these procedures are considered permanent and are generally NOT easily reversible.

questions.question:
Consider the following STDs:
(i) AIDS - caused by virus
(ii) Syphilis - caused by bacterium
(iii) Trichomoniasis - caused by fungus
(iv) Genital warts - caused by virus
Which are correctly matched?
questions.explanation: (i), (ii), and (iv) are correctly matched. (iii) is incorrect because Trichomoniasis is caused by a protozoan (Trichomonas vaginalis), not a fungus.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about contraceptive methods is INCORRECT?
(i) Barrier methods prevent physical contact between sperm and ovum.
(ii) Hormonal methods prevent ovulation.
(iii) IUDs increase sperm motility in the uterus.
(iv) Surgical methods block gamete transport.
questions.explanation: Statement (iii) is incorrect. IUDs DECREASE sperm motility (not increase it). Cu-T releases copper ions that are spermicidal, and hormonal IUDs thicken cervical mucus to impede sperm movement.

questions.question:
Read the following about reproductive health:
Statement I: India was the first country to initiate a family planning programme in 1951.
Statement II: The RCH programme pays attention to reproduction-related areas.
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct. India was indeed the first country in the world to initiate a national family planning programme in 1951. The RCH (Reproductive and Child Health) programmes provide comprehensive care for reproduction-related issues.

questions.question:
Consider the following:
(i) MTP is legal in India under certain conditions.
(ii) MTP is always safe regardless of gestational age.
(iii) MTP may be needed in cases of rape or contraceptive failure.
(iv) MTP is used to remove foetuses with genetic abnormalities.
Which are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (iii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (ii) is incorrect because MTP becomes increasingly unsafe with advancing gestational age. It is safest during the first trimester.

questions.question:
Read the statements:
Statement I: Natural methods of contraception have high failure rates.
Statement II: The rhythm method requires knowledge of the fertile period.
questions.explanation: Both are correct. Natural methods like periodic abstinence and withdrawal have relatively high failure rates compared to other methods. The rhythm method requires accurate knowledge of the woman's fertile period (days 10-17).

questions.question:
Consider the following:
(i) AIDS has no permanent cure.
(ii) Hepatitis B can be prevented by vaccination.
(iii) Syphilis can be cured with antibiotics.
(iv) Genital herpes can be completely cured with antiviral drugs.
How many statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Three statements are correct: (i), (ii), and (iii). Statement (iv) is incorrect because genital herpes cannot be completely cured; antiviral drugs can only manage symptoms and reduce outbreaks, but the virus remains in the body.

questions.question:
Match Column I (STD) with Column II (Causative organism):
Column I: (P) Syphilis, (Q) Gonorrhoea, (R) Genital herpes, (S) Chlamydiasis
Column II: (i) Neisseria, (ii) Chlamydia, (iii) HSV, (iv) Treponema
questions.explanation: Syphilis - Treponema pallidum (iv), Gonorrhoea - Neisseria gonorrhoeae (i), Genital herpes - HSV (iii), Chlamydiasis - Chlamydia trachomatis (ii).

questions.question:
Match Column I (ART) with Column II (Description):
Column I: (P) IVF, (Q) ZIFT, (R) GIFT, (S) ICSI
Column II: (i) Ovum + sperm into fallopian tube, (ii) Single sperm injected into ovum, (iii) Zygote into fallopian tube, (iv) Fertilisation in lab
questions.explanation: IVF - fertilisation in laboratory (iv), ZIFT - zygote transfer into fallopian tube (iii), GIFT - ovum and sperm transfer into fallopian tube (i), ICSI - single sperm injection into ovum (ii).

questions.question:
Match Column I (Contraceptive) with Column II (Type):
Column I: (P) Condom, (Q) Cu-T, (R) Oral pills, (S) Vasectomy
Column II: (i) Hormonal, (ii) IUD, (iii) Surgical, (iv) Barrier
questions.explanation: Condom - Barrier method (iv), Cu-T - IUD (ii), Oral pills - Hormonal method (i), Vasectomy - Surgical method (iii).

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II:
Column I: (P) Barrier methods, (Q) IUDs, (R) Hormonal methods, (S) Natural methods
Column II: (i) Prevent ovulation, (ii) Prevent physical contact of gametes, (iii) Based on fertile period awareness, (iv) Create hostile uterine environment
questions.explanation: Barrier methods prevent physical contact of gametes (ii), IUDs create a hostile uterine environment (iv), Hormonal methods prevent ovulation (i), and Natural methods are based on fertility awareness (iii).

questions.question:
Match Column I (IUD) with Column II (Type):
Column I: (P) Cu-T, (Q) LNG-20, (R) Multiload 375, (S) Lippes loop
Column II: (i) First generation IUD, (ii) Hormone-releasing, (iii) Copper-releasing, (iv) Copper-releasing
questions.explanation: Cu-T is copper-releasing (iii), LNG-20 is hormone-releasing (ii), Multiload 375 is copper-releasing (iv), and Lippes loop is a first-generation non-medicated IUD (i).

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II:
Column I: (P) Amniocentesis, (Q) MTP, (R) Tubectomy, (S) IVF-ET
Column II: (i) Termination of pregnancy, (ii) Prenatal diagnosis, (iii) Female sterilisation, (iv) Infertility treatment
questions.explanation: Amniocentesis is for prenatal diagnosis (ii), MTP is termination of pregnancy (i), Tubectomy is female sterilisation (iii), and IVF-ET is an infertility treatment (iv).

questions.question:
Match Column I (STD) with Column II (Type of pathogen):
Column I: (P) AIDS, (Q) Syphilis, (R) Trichomoniasis, (S) Candidiasis
Column II: (i) Protozoan, (ii) Bacterium, (iii) Virus, (iv) Fungus
questions.explanation: AIDS is caused by virus HIV (iii), Syphilis by bacterium Treponema pallidum (ii), Trichomoniasis by protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis (i), and Candidiasis by fungus Candida (iv).

questions.question:
How many of the following are bacterial STDs?
Syphilis, Gonorrhoea, Chlamydiasis, AIDS, Genital herpes, Trichomoniasis, Hepatitis B, Genital warts
questions.explanation: Three are bacterial STDs: Syphilis (Treponema pallidum), Gonorrhoea (Neisseria gonorrhoeae), and Chlamydiasis (Chlamydia trachomatis). AIDS, Genital herpes, Hepatitis B, and Genital warts are viral. Trichomoniasis is protozoal.

questions.question:
How many of the following are barrier methods of contraception?
Condom, Diaphragm, Cervical cap, Cu-T, Vault, Oral pills
questions.explanation: Four are barrier methods: Condom (male/female), Diaphragm, Cervical cap, and Vault. Cu-T is an IUD and Oral pills are hormonal methods. All four barrier methods physically prevent sperm from reaching the ovum.

questions.question:
How many of the following are viral STDs?
AIDS, Genital herpes, Hepatitis B, Genital warts, Syphilis, Gonorrhoea
questions.explanation: Four are viral STDs: AIDS (HIV), Genital herpes (HSV), Hepatitis B (HBV), and Genital warts (HPV). Syphilis and Gonorrhoea are bacterial STDs.

questions.question:
How many of the following ART techniques require in vitro fertilisation?
IVF-ET, ZIFT, GIFT, IUI, ICSI, Surrogacy
questions.explanation: Three techniques require in vitro fertilisation: IVF-ET (in vitro fertilisation and embryo transfer), ZIFT (zygote formed in vitro, then transferred), and ICSI (sperm injected into ovum in vitro). GIFT and IUI do not involve in vitro fertilisation.

questions.question:
How many of the following are methods to increase public awareness about reproductive health?
Audio-visual media, Print media, Government agencies, NGOs, Schools and colleges, Religious institutions
questions.explanation: Five methods are used: Audio-visual media, Print media, Government agencies, NGOs, and Schools/colleges. These platforms help in disseminating information about reproductive health, contraception, and STD prevention.

questions.question:
How many of the following are copper-releasing IUDs?
Cu-T, Cu-7, Multiload 375, LNG-20, Progestasert, Lippes loop
questions.explanation: Three are copper-releasing IUDs: Cu-T, Cu-7, and Multiload 375. LNG-20 and Progestasert are hormone-releasing IUDs. Lippes loop is a non-medicated (first generation) IUD.

questions.question:
How many of the following STDs are incurable?
AIDS, Genital herpes, Hepatitis B, Syphilis, Gonorrhoea, Genital warts
questions.explanation: Three STDs are incurable: AIDS (HIV), Genital herpes (HSV), and Hepatitis B (HBV - can be managed but not cured). Genital warts (HPV) can recur. Syphilis and Gonorrhoea are curable with antibiotics.

questions.question:
Arrange the following steps of IVF-ET in correct sequence:
(i) Transfer of embryo to uterus
(ii) Collection of ova and sperm
(iii) In vitro fertilisation
(iv) Embryo development in laboratory
(v) Hormonal stimulation of ovaries
questions.explanation: Correct sequence: Hormonal stimulation of ovaries (superovulation) → Collection of ova and sperm → In vitro fertilisation → Embryo development in laboratory → Transfer of embryo to uterus.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in order from least effective to most effective contraceptive method:
(i) Condoms
(ii) Sterilisation
(iii) Periodic abstinence
(iv) Oral pills
questions.explanation: From least to most effective: Periodic abstinence (highest failure rate) → Condoms → Oral pills → Sterilisation (most effective, nearly 100%).

questions.question:
Arrange the following stages of amniocentesis in correct order:
(i) Chromosomal analysis
(ii) Insertion of needle into amniotic cavity
(iii) Collection of amniotic fluid
(iv) Ultrasound guidance
(v) Analysis and diagnosis
questions.explanation: Correct sequence: Ultrasound guidance → Insertion of needle → Collection of amniotic fluid → Chromosomal analysis of foetal cells → Analysis and diagnosis of abnormalities.

questions.question:
Arrange the following government initiatives for population control in chronological order:
(i) RCH programme
(ii) Family Planning Programme (1951)
(iii) National Population Policy (2000)
(iv) Family Welfare Programme
questions.explanation: Chronological order: Family Planning Programme (1951) → Family Welfare Programme (renamed) → RCH programme → National Population Policy (2000).

questions.question:
Arrange the following contraceptive methods from temporary to permanent:
(i) Tubectomy
(ii) Condom
(iii) IUD
(iv) Oral pills
questions.explanation: From temporary to permanent: Condom (single use) → IUD (medium-term, removable) → Oral pills (daily, reversible) → Tubectomy (permanent sterilisation). Actually all except tubectomy are temporary; the order from shortest to longest acting is: Condom → IUD → Oral pills → Tubectomy.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in the order of steps for artificial insemination:
(i) Introduction of semen into female tract
(ii) Collection of semen from husband/donor
(iii) Processing and concentration of semen
(iv) Monitoring for pregnancy
questions.explanation: Correct sequence: Collection of semen → Processing and concentration of semen → Introduction of semen into female reproductive tract → Monitoring for pregnancy.

questions.question:
Arrange the following causes of infertility from most to least common:
(i) Blocked fallopian tubes
(ii) Low sperm count
(iii) Hormonal imbalances
(iv) Physical inability for coitus
questions.explanation: Common causes of infertility from most to least: Hormonal imbalances (most common) → Blocked fallopian tubes → Low sperm count → Physical inability for coitus. Hormonal issues affect both males and females.

questions.question: Which of the following IUDs releases copper ions to prevent conception?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, Multiload 375 is a copper-releasing IUD that increases phagocytosis of sperms within the uterus. LNG-20 and Progestasert are hormone-releasing IUDs, while Lippes Loop is a non-medicated IUD.

questions.question: Chlamydiasis is caused by:
questions.explanation: Chlamydiasis is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It is one of the most common bacterial STDs. Treponema causes syphilis, Neisseria causes gonorrhoea, and HPV causes genital warts.

questions.question: Saheli, the oral contraceptive developed by CDRI, contains:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, Saheli is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive developed by CDRI, Lucknow. It contains centchroman and is taken once a week. Unlike hormonal pills, it has very few side effects and high contraceptive value.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a measure to prevent STDs?
questions.explanation: Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy but do NOT provide protection against sexually transmitted diseases. Only barrier methods like condoms provide protection against STDs. Other preventive measures include avoiding multiple partners and early detection.

questions.question: India was among the first countries to initiate a national family planning programme in:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, India was amongst the first countries in the world to initiate action plans and programmes at a national level to attain total reproductive health as a social goal. The national family planning programme was started in 1952.

questions.question: Genital herpes is caused by:
questions.explanation: Genital herpes is caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV-2). It causes painful blisters in the genital area. HPV causes genital warts, Hepatitis B affects the liver, and HIV causes AIDS.

questions.question: Which ART technique involves transfer of an embryo with more than 8 blastomeres into the uterus?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, in IUT (Intra Uterine Transfer), embryos with more than 8 blastomeres are transferred into the uterus. ZIFT involves transfer of zygote or early embryo (up to 8 blastomeres) into the fallopian tube. GIFT involves transfer of unfertilised ovum and sperm.

questions.question: Which of the following complications can result from untreated gonorrhoea in females?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, complications of untreated STDs like gonorrhoea include pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and other reproductive complications. Cervical cancer is associated with HPV.

questions.question: Lactational amenorrhoea as a natural contraceptive method is effective up to a maximum of:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, lactational amenorrhoea (absence of menstruation during lactation) is effective as a natural contraceptive method only up to 6 months after parturition. After this period, ovulation may resume even during breastfeeding.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non-medicated IUD?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, IUDs are classified as non-medicated (like Lippes Loop), copper-releasing (Cu-T, Cu-7, Multiload 375), and hormone-releasing (Progestasert, LNG-20). Non-medicated IUDs work by creating a physical barrier.

questions.question: Spermicidal creams and jellies are examples of:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, spermicidal creams, jellies, and foams are chemical barriers that kill or immobilise sperms. They are used along with physical barriers like diaphragms and cervical caps for better efficacy.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE about MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy)?
options: It is legal in India for any stage of pregnancy
It is safe and legal up to 12 weeks of pregnancy
It is used as a regular contraceptive method
It does not require medical supervision
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, MTP is considered safe during the first trimester (up to 12 weeks). It is relatively riskier in the second trimester. MTP is not a contraceptive method and should not be used as one. It requires proper medical supervision.

questions.question: In GIFT, which of the following is transferred into the fallopian tube?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, GIFT (Gamete Intra Fallopian Transfer) involves transfer of an ovum collected from a donor along with sperms into the fallopian tube of the woman who cannot produce ova but can provide suitable environment for fertilisation and development.

questions.question: Which of the following is a major cause of population explosion in India?
options: Decline in death rate with stable birth rate
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the major reason for population explosion is the decline in death rate, maternal mortality rate, and infant mortality rate due to better medical facilities, while the birth rate has remained comparatively high.

questions.question: The statutory age for marriage in India is:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the statutory age for marriage in India is 18 years for females and 21 years for males. This measure was taken as a step to control population growth by delaying the reproductive age.

questions.question: Which of the following causes infertility in males due to inability to produce sperms?
options: Very low sperm count in ejaculate
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, infertility in males can be due to physical inability to inseminate the female, very low sperm count in the ejaculate, or blocked vas deferens. Females may be infertile due to blocked fallopian tubes, uterine abnormalities, or hormonal imbalances.

questions.question: Progestasert and LNG-20 IUDs make the uterus unsuitable for implantation by:
options: Releasing hormones that change uterine environment
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, hormone-releasing IUDs like Progestasert (releases progesterone) and LNG-20 (releases levonorgestrel) make the uterus unsuitable for implantation and also make the cervical mucus hostile to sperms.

questions.question: Which of the following STDs is caused by a protozoan?
questions.explanation: Trichomoniasis is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a protozoan parasite. Syphilis (Treponema) and gonorrhoea (Neisseria) are bacterial STDs, while genital herpes is caused by Herpes simplex virus.

questions.question: Amniocentesis was banned in India because it was being misused for:
options: Determining sex of the foetus leading to female foeticide
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, amniocentesis is a technique for prenatal diagnosis of genetic and chromosomal abnormalities. It was banned in India for sex determination because it was being misused to determine the sex of the foetus, leading to female foeticide.

questions.question: Which of the following STDs cannot be cured completely?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, diseases like AIDS and Hepatitis B are incurable because they are caused by viruses. Bacterial STDs like gonorrhoea, syphilis, and chlamydiasis can be treated and cured with appropriate antibiotics if detected early.

questions.question: Cervical caps and vaults are barrier contraceptives used by:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cervical caps and vaults are barrier contraceptive devices used by females. They are placed over the cervix during coitus to prevent sperms from entering the uterus. Male barrier methods include condoms.

questions.question: Improved health care facilities have led to rapid decline in which of the following, contributing to population explosion?
options: Death rate and infant mortality rate
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, rapid decline in death rate, maternal mortality rate (MMR) and infant mortality rate (IMR) due to better medical facilities and awareness has been a major cause of population explosion, while the birth rate has not declined proportionately.
